channel.title: Porn Popularity vs. Rape Incidents
channel.description:
http://jurist.law.pitt.edu/forumy/2006/06/rape-porn-and-criminality-political.php
There is, however, one social factor that correlates almost exactly with the rape statistics. The American public is probably not ready to believe it. My theory is that the sharp rise in access to pornography accounts for the decline in rape. The correlation is inverse: the more pornography, the less rape. It is like the inverse correlation: the more police officers on the street, the less crime.

item.title: Porn Popularity vs. Rape Incidents
item.dc:creator: @fellixombc fellixombc
item.description:
@fellixombc wrote:

[quote=“Hyjall, post:30, topic:171626”][quote author=JDB` link=topic=231678.msg1983874#msg1983874 date=1199742415]

Rapers often come from families which have rapings in their history, because this behavior is taught when you’re still young and thus are easily convinced, it pays a great deal in your further life and might have effect whether you will commit rape or not.

Whilst this is true for some situations, it is not always that it had happened in their childhood, or at all for that matter, rapists aren’t ‘convinced’, per say, to commit the rapes but rather conditioned by one means or another, whether it be childhood abuse or just mental illness. However don’t get me wrong, sometimes rape is just because someone is horny/worked up and then someone says no.

PS: Are you christian?

This made me lol, I was wondering myself if he has strong christian/catholic influence in his family.
[/quote]

Convinced was merely a filler until I had a better word to describe it (:.

Offtopic: Who is JDB?

TherealJdb
Mods seem to have gone with the fashion of coating your name with a cool IRC’ish style

Rapers often come from families which have rapings in their history, because this behavior is taught when you’re still young and thus are easily convinced, it pays a great deal in your further life and might have effect whether you will commit rape or not.

Whilst this is true for some situations, it is not always that it had happened in their childhood, or at all for that matter, rapists aren’t ‘convinced’, per say, to commit the rapes but rather conditioned by one means or another, whether it be childhood abuse or just mental illness. However don’t get me wrong, sometimes rape is just because someone is horny/worked up and then someone says no.

PS: Are you christian?

This made me lol, I was wondering myself if he has strong christian/catholic influence in his family.

just saying. and no im not cathlioc, im lutheran and that has nothing to do with raping?

It has nothing to with raping indeed, it has something to do with your general and one sided view of pornography since most always strict christian families are against pornography masturbation etc.[/quote]
Thats fricken catholic, some my friends can’t even date.

item.title: Porn Popularity vs. Rape Incidents
item.dc:creator: @Hyjall Hyjall
item.description:
@Hyjall wrote:

fellixombc:

porn out of all is bad, you will eventually rape someone.

I find it funny how you can just make claims without having anything to back it up.

Rapers often come from families which have rapings in their history, because this behavior is taught when you’re still young and thus are easily convinced, it pays a great deal in your further life and might have effect whether you will commit rape or not. Porn, however, will be introduced to you at your later years. This means that it will have a much lesser impact on your life.
So saying that porn will make 100% sure that you will rape someone eventually is one of the most ignorant comments I have ever seen on these boards(including moparisthebest.com), and that says something.

PS: Are you christian?

Read full topic

item.title: Porn Popularity vs. Rape Incidents
item.dc:creator: @Taios Taios
item.description:
@Taios wrote:

[quote=“VB7 Rocks, post:2, topic:171626”]Exactly.

More video games, less killing in real life is probably another one.

(I’m just tired of people against things like video games and porn sites.)[/quote]

That, even as a video game fan i do not agree with.

Some games go into great lengths of detail into killing, cutting, slicing, shooting etc. Something you would not usually see in every day life. Seeing more violence provokes more violence.

I know a young person who after playing grand theft auto, anytime you annoyed him. ‘Im gonna kill you now’, also started exercising violent behavior…They were stopped from playing it and now are sound :).

How does a video game remove your frustration and violence? If i’m pissed off i might go play a game to chill out but if i get angry, a games not going to stop anything that follows it. Its quite easy to loose yourself in games and get depression.

Please note. This comes from a huge Resident evil fan. I also have a ps3 and a good few games.

As for the porn stuff, i guess that relieves sexual tension which would course rape?

Games could however allow expression of anger if you play a ‘beat em up game’. However if you loose, you can find yourself getting even more angry lol.

There are exceptions to all cases however if people were kept to the game ages i reckon it would be fine and it wouldn’t have any violent impact because people actually properly know real from fake. A 11 year old playing an 18 game(yup, I’ve done it. haven’t we all.) (no matter how old they think they are) is not good. I do learning support with children ages 12-13, one whom has learning difficulties (ADHD). He brags about all the films he watches, grudge, scary movie etc. He says he’s old enough to watch them all. Well from his perspective yes, however everytime he disrupts the class its with a quote from a game or film(which is inappropriate). (someone got a question wrong and he shouts out ‘You been smokin too much marawana’)

parents play a major part.

Read full topic

item.title: Porn Popularity vs. Rape Incidents
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

I think libido is best viewed in the same way intelligence is viewed. It is constant; all that is variable is what you do with it. Proceeding under the assumption that the libido is constant, it makes sense that one who has satisfied himself through pornography will not be as affected by sexual stimulation as, say, the abstinent.

Read full topic
